Award.AwardTitle: International Collaboration in Chemistry: A Theoretical Investigation Of The Role Of The Chemical Bond In The Raman And Fluorescence Response Of Molecule-Nanoparticle Hybrids
Award.AbstractNarration:
Vladimiro Mujica at Arizona State University is funded by the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in an International Collaboration in Chemistry, with partners Arne Keller at the University of Paris in Orsay as well as Osman Atabek and Monica Calatayd all funded by France's Agence Nationale de la Recherche. This is co-funded by the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE). This project aims at a theoretical investigation of the influence of the chemical bond between a molecule and a semiconducting nanoparticle on the Raman and fluorescence responses of these hybrid systems. These processes must be jointly considered, as the excitation and decay pathways become interdependent due to the appearance of midgap states, induced by the formation of the chemical bond and interfacial charge transfer that play a fundamental role in both photoexcitation and electron injection into the nanoparticle. This involves the calculation of the cross section for both Raman scattering and fluorescence, based on the properties of the time-correlation function of the effective dipole moment of the system. The emphasis is on processes that are resonant in the hybrid but not in the separate components, due to the reduction of the energy gap for electron excitation. Laser photoexcitation simultaneously provokes the creation of an electron-hole exciton and probes the Raman and fluorescence responses.

By developing reliable procedures to predict the light that emerges when laser light shines on these molecule-nanoparticle hybrid systems, greater understanding will be obtained of the fundamental physical and chemical processes in bio-sensors and also in solar cells and photocatalysis. These three areas are crucial for energy and health-related research and for the technological implementation of new photovoltaic devices and sensors. The project involves a strong international scientific cooperation between teams of researchers in France and the U.S and it also contemplates active collaboration with experimental groups and human resources formation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advances in the most pressing technological challenges of these times, e.g., medicine, environment and energy, depend to a large extent on our ability to fabricate and design new material structures and control their functions. Using nano-structures consisting of a metal oxide nano-particle and an adsorbed molecule as molecular sensors and devices for solar cells, depend on our knowledge of how charge transfer processes at the interface between the molecule and the nanoparticle affect the optical response of the nano-structure to the interaction with light. 

In this project, a team of US, France and Brazil researchers have joined forces to study systematically how two important optical responses: (i) Raman spectroscopy, a molecular response to changes in the molecular polarizability induced by the external electromagnetic field, and (ii) fluorescence, a molecular electronic relaxation process, are controlled by the interfacial charge transfer arising from the formation of chemical bonds between the molecule and the nano-particle. Our research journey has taken us to use a combination of advanced computational and theoretical techniques to first describe the nature of the chemical bond in these structures and second to understand how the process of bond formation is ultimately responsible for the appearance of electronic states that facilitate the absorption of light and the activation of excitation and relaxation processes that determine the optical response. 

Our research proposal was inspired in the surprising experimental observation of the enhancement of the Raman intensity in a system, titanium dioxide nano-particles coated with dopamine, a phenomenon that according to the literature on the subject shouldn't occur. This pioneering work, done in collaboration between researchers at Northwestern University and Argonne National Laboratory led us to apply for funding from NSF to expand our knowledge in this new field. Our work in the context of this International Collaboration NSF project has led to the publication of more than 10 original research articles as well as several presentations in international scientific events. It has also contributed to the education of several postdoctoral fellows and graduate students both at Arizona State University and the University of Paris at Orsay and Jussie campuses.

We have now a relatively complete picture of how the original excitation event induced by the absorption of light by the nano-particle/molecule system, translates into a complex process involving relaxation, emission, and electron-hole recombination, which intervene in the optical response of the system. We have also advanced our understanding of how the environment, specifically the solvent, plays a paramount role on the optical response of the system. In the course of these investigations we have developed new computational and analytical tools and a broader comprehension of how the different phenomena involved in the optical response are also related to catalysis and the potential use of these hybrid nano-systems as photovoltaic devices.
